docs.text: By contributing to Canvas CLI, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the MIT License.

docs.title: Recognition
docs.text:
Contributors will be recognized in: - GitHub contributors page - Release notes - Project README (for significant contributions)

Thank you for contributing to Canvas CLI! 🎉

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to Canvas CLI! This guide will help you get up and running quickly.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Canvas CLI is a command-line interface for interacting with Canvas LMS. It provides comprehensive access to Canvas API features including:

  • Course management
  • Assignment and submission handling
  • User management
  • Module and page management
  • File operations
  • Calendar and planner integration

docs.title: Quick Setup
docs.text:
1. Install Canvas CLI using your preferred method
  2. Authenticate with your Canvas instance
  3. Start using commands to interact with Canvas

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Installation

    Multiple installation methods including Homebrew, Go, and binary downloads

    Install now

  • Authentication

    Set up OAuth authentication with your Canvas instance

    Authenticate

  • Quick Start

    Get started with common commands in 5 minutes

    Quick start

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Go 1.21+ (if installing from source)
  • Canvas LMS account with API access
  • API Token or OAuth credentials

docs.title: Authentication Guide
docs.text: Canvas CLI uses OAuth 2.0 for secure authentication with Canvas LMS. This guide covers everything you need to set up and manage authentication.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
The simplest way to authenticate:

canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com

This will: 1. Open your browser to Canvas 2. Ask you to authorize the application 3. Automatically save your credentials securely

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Developer Key (Optional)
docs.text:
By default, Canvas CLI uses embedded OAuth credentials. For enhanced security or custom integrations, you can create your own:

  1. Log into Canvas as an administrator
  2. Navigate to Admin > Developer Keys
  3. Click + Developer Key > + API Key
  4. Fill in the details:
  5. Key Name: Canvas CLI
  6. Owner Email: your-email@example.com
  7. Redirect URIs: http://localhost:8080/callback (or your preferred port)
  8. Scopes: Select all required scopes
  9. Save and note your Client ID and Client Secret

docs.title: Using Embedded Credentials (Easiest)
docs.text: canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com

docs.title: Using Your Own Credentials
docs.text:
canvas auth login \
  --instance https://canvas.instructure.com \
  --client-id YOUR_CLIENT_ID \
  --client-secret YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Authentication
docs.text:
# Check authentication status
canvas auth status

# Test with a simple API call
canvas courses list

docs.title: Local Browser Flow (Default)
docs.text:
The CLI starts a local web server and opens your browser:

canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com

This is the most user-friendly method and works on most systems.

docs.title: Out-of-Band (OOB) Flow
docs.text:
For systems without a browser or remote SSH sessions:

canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com --oob

This will: 1. Display an authorization URL 2. Ask you to visit it manually 3. Prompt you to paste the authorization code

docs.title: Environment Variables (CI/CD)
docs.text:
For automated workflows and CI/CD pipelines, Canvas CLI supports authentication via environment variables:

# Required environment variables
export CANVAS_URL="https://canvas.instructure.com"
export CANVAS_TOKEN="your-access-token"

# Optional: Control rate limiting (default: 5.0)
export CANVAS_REQUESTS_PER_SEC="10.0"

# Commands will use these automatically
canvas courses list

How to get your access token:

  1. Log into Canvas
  2. Go to Account > Settings > Approved Integrations
  3. Click + New Access Token
  4. Copy the token (it will only be shown once)

Priority Order:

Canvas CLI checks for credentials in this order: 1. Environment variables (CANVAS_URL + CANVAS_TOKEN) - highest priority 2. Config file (~/.canvas-cli/config.yaml) 3. OAuth tokens (stored in system keychain)

CI/CD Example (GitHub Actions):

name: Canvas CI
on: [push]
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Run Canvas CLI
        env:
          CANVAS_URL: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_URL }}
          CANVAS_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_TOKEN }}
        run: |
          canvas courses list
          canvas assignments list --course-id 123

docs.title: Multi-Instance Management
docs.text: Canvas CLI supports multiple Canvas installations:

docs.title: Add Multiple Instances
docs.text:
# Add production instance
canvas config add --name production --url https://canvas.instructure.com

# Add staging instance
canvas config add --name staging --url https://staging.canvas.instructure.com

# Add self-hosted instance
canvas config add --name onprem --url https://canvas.company.com

docs.title: Switch Between Instances
docs.text:
# List all instances
canvas config list

# Switch to a different instance
canvas config use staging

# Use a specific instance for one command
canvas courses list --instance production

docs.title: Authenticate Each Instance
docs.text:
# Authenticate with each instance separately
canvas auth login --instance production
canvas auth login --instance staging
canvas auth login --instance onprem

docs.title: Credential Storage
docs.text:
Canvas CLI stores credentials securely using your system's native keychain:

  • macOS: Keychain
  • Linux: Secret Service API (gnome-keyring, kwallet)
  • Windows: Windows Credential Manager

docs.title: Fallback Storage
docs.text:
If keychain access fails, credentials are stored in encrypted files:

  • Location: ~/.canvas-cli/credentials.enc
  • Encryption: AES-256-GCM with machine-specific key
  • Key Derivation: Machine ID + username

docs.title: Manual Credential Management
docs.text:
# View stored credentials (won't show tokens)
canvas auth status

# Logout (removes credentials)
canvas auth logout

# Logout from specific instance
canvas auth logout --instance staging

# Logout from all instances
canvas auth logout --all

docs.title: Token Refresh
docs.text: Access tokens expire after 1 hour. Canvas CLI automatically refreshes them using refresh tokens.

docs.title: Token Permissions (Scopes)
docs.text:
Canvas CLI requests the following OAuth scopes:

  • url:GET|/api/v1/courses - Read courses
  • url:POST|/api/v1/courses - Create courses
  • url:PUT|/api/v1/courses/:id - Update courses
  • url:DELETE|/api/v1/courses/:id - Delete courses
  • Similar patterns for assignments, submissions, users, files

docs.title: Manual Token Usage
docs.text:
If you have an access token:

# Use directly
canvas courses list --token YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

# Or set environment variable
export CANVAS_TOKEN="YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN"
canvas courses list

docs.title: 1. Use System Keychain
docs.text: Always allow Canvas CLI to use your system keychain when prompted.

docs.title: 2. Rotate Tokens Regularly
docs.text:
# Logout and login again to get fresh tokens
canvas auth logout
canvas auth login

docs.title: 3. Limit Scope
docs.text: When creating developer keys, only grant necessary scopes.

docs.title: 4. Use Environment Variables for CI/CD
docs.text:
For automated systems, use environment variables instead of storing credentials in code:

# Example GitHub Actions workflow
env:
  CANVAS_URL: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_URL }}
  CANVAS_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_TOKEN }}

docs.title: 5. Keep Credentials Private
docs.text:
Never commit tokens or credentials to version control:

# Add to .gitignore
echo ".canvas-cli/" >> .gitignore

docs.title: "Failed to open browser"
docs.text:
Use OOB flow: 

canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com --oob

docs.title: "Failed to access keychain"
docs.text: Grant permission in system settings or use encrypted file storage (automatic fallback).

docs.title: "Token expired"
docs.text:
Tokens refresh automatically. If refresh fails: 

canvas auth logout
canvas auth login

docs.title: "Unauthorized" or "403 Forbidden"
docs.text:
Check your OAuth scopes or Canvas permissions: 

canvas auth status

docs.title: "CORS errors"
docs.text: Ensure your Canvas instance allows OAuth from localhost: - Check Developer Key redirect URIs - Verify Canvas OAuth settings

docs.title: Custom Redirect Port
docs.text:
canvas auth login \
  --instance https://canvas.instructure.com \
  --port 9000

docs.title: Specify Redirect URI
docs.text:
canvas auth login \
  --instance https://canvas.instructure.com \
  --redirect-uri http://localhost:8080/callback

docs.title: Debug Authentication
docs.text: canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com --debug

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: After authentication: - Command Reference - Learn available commands - Tutorials - See common use cases - Test your setup: canvas courses list

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide covers all the ways to install Canvas CLI on your system.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Operating Systems: macOS, Linux, Windows
  • Architecture: amd64, arm64
  • Go Version (if building from source): 1.21 or later

docs.title: Method 1: Homebrew (macOS/Linux) - Recommended
docs.text:
# Add the Canvas CLI tap
brew tap jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli

# Install Canvas CLI
brew install canvas-cli

# Verify installation
canvas version

docs.title: Upgrading
docs.text: brew upgrade canvas-cli

docs.title: Method 2: Using Go
docs.text:
If you have Go installed:

# Install latest version
go install github.com/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli/cmd/canvas@latest

# Install specific version
go install github.com/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli/cmd/canvas@v1.0.0

# Verify installation
canvas version

docs.title: Method 3: Download Binary (All Platforms)
docs.text:
1. Visit the Releases page
  2. Download the appropriate binary for your platform:
  3. macOS (Intel): canvas_v1.0.0_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz
  4. macOS (Apple Silicon): canvas_v1.0.0_Darwin_arm64.tar.gz
  5. Linux (64-bit): canvas_v1.0.0_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz

  6. Windows (64-bit): canvas_v1.0.0_Windows_x86_64.zip

  7. Extract the archive: 

    # macOS/Linux
tar -xzf canvas_*.tar.gz

# Windows - use your preferred extraction tool

  8. Move the binary to your PATH: 

    # macOS/Linux
sudo mv canvas /usr/local/bin/

# Windows - add to PATH or move to C:\Windows\System32\

  9. Verify installation: 

    canvas version

docs.title: Method 4: Docker
docs.text:
# Run Canvas CLI in Docker
docker run ghcr.io/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli:latest version

# Create an alias for easier use
alias canvas='docker run -it --rm -v ~/.canvas-cli:/root/.canvas-cli ghcr.io/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli:latest'

# Now use as normal
canvas courses list

docs.title: Method 5: Build from Source
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli.git
cd canvas-cli

# Build
make build

# Install
make install

# Verify
canvas version

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text: Enable tab completion for your shell:

docs.title: Bash
docs.text:
# Generate completion script
canvas completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/canvas

# Or for user-level installation
canvas completion bash > ~/.canvas-completion.bash
echo 'source ~/.canvas-completion.bash' >> ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:
# Generate completion script
canvas completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_canvas"

# Reload completions
autoload -U compinit && compinit

docs.title: Fish
docs.text:
# Generate completion script
canvas completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/canvas.fish

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text:
# Generate completion script
canvas completion powershell | Out-String | Invoke-Expression

# Add to profile for persistence
canvas completion powershell >> $PROFILE

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify everything is working:

# Check version
canvas version

# Run diagnostics
canvas doctor

# Test authentication (will prompt for credentials)
canvas auth login --instance https://canvas.instructure.com

docs.title: Command not found
docs.text:
If you get command not found, ensure the installation directory is in your PATH:

# Check PATH
echo $PATH

# Add to PATH (macOS/Linux)
export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/bin"

# Make permanent by adding to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
echo 'export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/bin"' >> ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Permission denied
docs.text:
If you get permission errors:

# Make binary executable
chmod +x /path/to/canvas

# Or use sudo for installation
sudo mv canvas /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: macOS Security Warning
docs.text:
On macOS, you may need to allow the app in System Preferences:

  1. Try to run canvas version
  2. Go to System Preferences > Security & Privacy
  3. Click "Allow Anyway" for Canvas CLI
  4. Run the command again

docs.title: Homebrew
docs.text: brew upgrade canvas-cli

docs.title: Go
docs.text: go install github.com/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli/cmd/canvas@latest

docs.title: Binary
docs.text: Download and replace the binary with the latest version from the releases page.

docs.title: Docker
docs.text: docker pull ghcr.io/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli:latest

docs.title: Homebrew
docs.text:
brew uninstall canvas-cli
brew untap jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli

docs.title: Go
docs.text: rm $(which canvas)

docs.title: Binary
docs.text:
# Find and remove the binary
sudo rm /usr/local/bin/canvas

# Remove configuration and cache
rm -rf ~/.canvas-cli

docs.title: Docker
docs.text: docker rmi ghcr.io/jjuanrivvera/canvas-cli:latest

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: After installation, continue with: - Authentication Guide - Set up OAuth - Command Reference - Learn available commands - Tutorials - See common use cases

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with Canvas CLI in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Canvas CLI installed (Installation Guide)
  • Canvas LMS account with API access

docs.title: Step 1: Authenticate
docs.text:
First, authenticate with your Canvas instance:

canvas auth login

This will open your browser for OAuth authentication. After authorizing, you'll be redirected back to the CLI.

API Token Alternative

If OAuth isn't available, you can use an API token: 

canvas config add --name mycanvas --url https://canvas.example.com --token YOUR_API_TOKEN

docs.title: Step 2: Verify Authentication
docs.text:
Check that you're authenticated:

canvas auth status

You should see your user information and the Canvas instance URL.

docs.title: Step 3: List Your Courses
docs.text:
canvas courses list

This shows all courses you have access to. Note the course IDs for use in other commands.

docs.title: Step 4: Explore Course Content
docs.text:
# List assignments
canvas assignments list --course-id 123

# List users in a course
canvas users list --course-id 123

# List modules
canvas modules list --course-id 123

docs.title: Step 5: Try Different Output Formats
docs.text:
Canvas CLI supports multiple output formats:

Table (default)JSONYAMLCSV 
canvas courses list

canvas courses list --output json

canvas courses list --output yaml

canvas courses list --output csv

docs.title: Common Commands
docs.text: Task Command List courses canvas courses list Get course details canvas courses get 123 List assignments canvas assignments list --course-id 123 Grade submission canvas submissions grade 456 --course-id 123 --score 95 List users canvas users list --course-id 123 Upload file canvas files upload ./file.pdf --course-id 123

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• User Guide - Learn more about configuration and features
  • Command Reference - Complete command documentation
  • Tutorials - Step-by-step guides for common tasks

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Canvas CLI can be configured using environment variables.

docs.title: Available Variables
docs.text: Variable Description Default CANVAS_INSTANCE Canvas instance URL From config CANVAS_TOKEN API access token From config/keyring CANVAS_OUTPUT Default output format table CANVAS_NO_CACHE Disable response caching false

docs.title: Temporary Override
docs.text:
Set for a single command:

CANVAS_OUTPUT=json canvas courses list

docs.title: Session Override
docs.text:
Set for the current shell session:

export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas.example.com
export CANVAS_TOKEN=your-api-token
canvas courses list

docs.title: Permanent Configuration
docs.text:
Add to your shell profile (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, etc.):

# Canvas CLI configuration
export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas.example.com
export CANVAS_TOKEN=your-api-token
export CANVAS_OUTPUT=json

docs.title: CANVAS_INSTANCE
docs.text:
The Canvas LMS instance URL.

export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas.instructure.com

Priority

Command-line --instance flag takes precedence over environment variable.

docs.title: CANVAS_TOKEN
docs.text:
Canvas API access token. Generate from Canvas Account Settings.

export CANVAS_TOKEN=7~AbCdEfGhIjKlMnOpQrStUvWxYz123456789

Security

Avoid setting tokens in shared environments. Consider using the config file or keyring instead.

docs.title: CANVAS_OUTPUT
docs.text:
Default output format for commands.

Value Description table Human-readable table (default) json JSON format yaml YAML format csv CSV format 
export CANVAS_OUTPUT=json

docs.title: CANVAS_NO_CACHE
docs.text:
Disable API response caching.

export CANVAS_NO_CACHE=true

When to Disable

Disable caching when you need real-time data or are debugging.

docs.title: Precedence Order
docs.text:
Configuration is applied in this order (highest precedence first):

  1. Command-line flags (--instance, --output, etc.)
  2. Environment variables
  3. Configuration file (~/.canvas-cli/config.yaml)
  4. Built-in defaults

docs.title: Development Environment
docs.text:
# Use sandbox instance
export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas-sandbox.example.com
export CANVAS_TOKEN=sandbox-token
export CANVAS_NO_CACHE=true

docs.title: CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text:
# GitHub Actions example
env:
  CANVAS_INSTANCE: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_URL }}
  CANVAS_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.CANVAS_TOKEN }}
  CANVAS_OUTPUT: json

docs.title: Multi-Instance Setup
docs.text:
# Function to switch instances
canvas-prod() {
  export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas.example.com
  export CANVAS_TOKEN=$CANVAS_PROD_TOKEN
}

canvas-sandbox() {
  export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas-sandbox.example.com
  export CANVAS_TOKEN=$CANVAS_SANDBOX_TOKEN
}

docs.title: Variable Not Working
docs.text:
1. Verify the variable is set: 

    echo $CANVAS_INSTANCE

  2. Check for typos in variable names

  3. Ensure you've sourced your profile: 

    source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Token Security
docs.text:
If your token is exposed:

  1. Immediately regenerate it in Canvas Account Settings
  2. Update your configuration
  3. Consider using the config file with restrictive permissions: 
    chmod 600 ~/.canvas-cli/config.yaml

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Canvas CLI uses standard exit codes to indicate command status.

docs.title: Exit Code Reference
docs.text: Code Name Description 0 Success Command completed successfully 1 General Error Unspecified error occurred 2 Usage Error Invalid command syntax or arguments 64 Usage Error Command line usage error (EX_USAGE) 65 Data Error Input data was incorrect (EX_DATAERR) 66 No Input Input file did not exist or was unreadable (EX_NOINPUT) 69 Unavailable Service unavailable (EX_UNAVAILABLE) 70 Software Error Internal software error (EX_SOFTWARE) 73 Can't Create Can't create output file (EX_CANTCREAT) 74 IO Error Input/output error (EX_IOERR) 75 Temp Failure Temporary failure, retry later (EX_TEMPFAIL) 77 Permission Denied Permission denied (EX_NOPERM) 78 Config Error Configuration error (EX_CONFIG)

docs.title: Success (0)
docs.text:
canvas courses list
echo $?  # Output: 0

docs.title: Authentication Error (77)
docs.text:
canvas courses list  # Without authentication
echo $?  # Output: 77

docs.title: Invalid Arguments (64)
docs.text:
canvas courses list --invalid-flag
echo $?  # Output: 64

docs.title: Resource Not Found (65)
docs.text:
canvas courses get 999999  # Non-existent course
echo $?  # Output: 65

docs.title: API Error (69)
docs.text:
# Canvas server unavailable
canvas courses list
echo $?  # Output: 69

docs.title: Basic Check
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
if canvas courses list -o json > courses.json; then
  echo "Success!"
else
  echo "Failed with exit code: $?"
  exit 1
fi

docs.title: Detailed Error Handling
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
canvas courses list -o json > courses.json
exit_code=$?

case $exit_code in
  0)
    echo "Success"
    ;;
  77)
    echo "Authentication required. Run: canvas auth login"
    exit 77
    ;;
  69)
    echo "Canvas server unavailable. Retrying in 60 seconds..."
    sleep 60
    exec "$0" "$@"  # Retry
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Failed with exit code: $exit_code"
    exit $exit_code
    ;;
esac

docs.title: Retry on Temporary Failure
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
MAX_RETRIES=3
RETRY_DELAY=10

for i in $(seq 1 $MAX_RETRIES); do
  canvas courses list -o json > courses.json
  exit_code=$?

  if [ $exit_code -eq 0 ]; then
    break
  elif [ $exit_code -eq 75 ] && [ $i -lt $MAX_RETRIES ]; then
    echo "Temporary failure, retry $i of $MAX_RETRIES..."
    sleep $RETRY_DELAY
  else
    echo "Failed after $i attempts"
    exit $exit_code
  fi
done

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
- name: Fetch Canvas Data
  run: |
    canvas courses list -o json > courses.json
  continue-on-error: false  # Fail the job on non-zero exit

- name: Handle Partial Failures
  run: |
    canvas courses list -o json > courses.json || {
      if [ $? -eq 75 ]; then
        echo "::warning::Temporary failure, data may be stale"
      else
        exit 1
      fi
    }

docs.title: Jenkins Pipeline
docs.text:
pipeline {
  stages {
    stage('Fetch Data') {
      steps {
        script {
          def exitCode = sh(
            script: 'canvas courses list -o json > courses.json',
            returnStatus: true
          )
          if (exitCode == 77) {
            error('Authentication required')
          } else if (exitCode != 0) {
            error("Canvas CLI failed with exit code: ${exitCode}")
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Always Check Exit Codes

In production scripts, always check and handle exit codes appropriately.

Log the Exit Code

When debugging, log the exit code along with any error messages: 

canvas courses list 2>&1
echo "Exit code: $?"

Don't Ignore Errors

Use set -e in bash scripts to exit on any error: 

#!/bin/bash
set -e
canvas courses list -o json > courses.json
# Script stops here if command fails

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text: Step-by-step guides for common Canvas CLI workflows.

docs.title: Available Tutorials
docs.text:
• Bulk Grading

    Grade multiple submissions efficiently using CSV files

    Bulk Grading

  • Course Sync

    Synchronize courses between Canvas instances

    Course Sync

  • Scripting & Automation

    Automate tasks with shell scripts and pipelines

    Scripting

docs.title: Quick Tips
docs.text:
Use JSON Output for Scripts

When writing scripts, always use -o json for reliable parsing: 

canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[].id'

Batch Operations

Canvas CLI supports concurrent batch operations for better performance: 

canvas submissions grade-batch --file grades.csv --course-id 123

Caching

Enable caching for repeated queries to reduce API calls: 

canvas courses list  # Cached for subsequent calls
canvas courses list --no-cache  # Force fresh data

docs.title: Bulk Grading Tutorial
docs.text: Learn how to grade multiple submissions efficiently using Canvas CLI.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Canvas CLI provides powerful bulk grading capabilities that allow you to:

  • Export submissions to CSV for offline grading
  • Import grades from CSV files
  • Grade with comments and rubric scores

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Canvas CLI installed and authenticated
  • Course ID and Assignment ID
  • Appropriate grading permissions

docs.title: Step 1: List Assignments
docs.text:
First, find the assignment you want to grade:

canvas assignments list --course-id 123

Output: 

ID     NAME                    DUE DATE              POINTS
456    Midterm Exam            2024-10-15 23:59      100
789    Final Project           2024-12-01 23:59      200

docs.title: Step 2: Export Submissions
docs.text:
Export all submissions for an assignment:

canvas submissions list --course-id 123 --assignment-id 456 -o csv > submissions.csv

The CSV file will contain: 

user_id,user_name,submission_type,submitted_at,score,grade
1001,John Doe,online_upload,2024-10-14T10:30:00Z,,
1002,Jane Smith,online_upload,2024-10-15T08:45:00Z,,

docs.title: Step 3: Grade Offline
docs.text:
Open the CSV in your spreadsheet application and add scores:

user_id,user_name,submission_type,submitted_at,score,grade,comment
1001,John Doe,online_upload,2024-10-14T10:30:00Z,85,B,Good work!
1002,Jane Smith,online_upload,2024-10-15T08:45:00Z,92,A-,Excellent analysis

docs.title: Step 4: Import Grades
docs.text:
Create a grades file with the required columns:

user_id,score,comment
1001,85,Good work!
1002,92,Excellent analysis

Import the grades:

canvas submissions grade-batch \
  --course-id 123 \
  --assignment-id 456 \
  --file grades.csv

docs.title: Step 5: Verify Grades
docs.text:
Check that grades were applied:

canvas submissions list --course-id 123 --assignment-id 456

docs.title: Advanced: Grading with Rubrics
docs.text:
If your assignment uses a rubric, you can include rubric scores:

user_id,score,rubric_assessment
1001,85,{"criterion_1":{"points":20},"criterion_2":{"points":15}}

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Batch Size

For large classes, grades are processed in batches automatically. The CLI handles rate limiting.

Grade Overwrites

Importing grades will overwrite existing grades. Export current grades first as a backup.

Dry Run

Test your CSV format by grading a single submission first: 

canvas submissions grade 1001 \
  --course-id 123 \
  --assignment-id 456 \
  --score 85 \
  --comment "Good work!"

docs.title: Complete Workflow Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
COURSE_ID=123
ASSIGNMENT_ID=456

# Export submissions
canvas submissions list \
  --course-id $COURSE_ID \
  --assignment-id $ASSIGNMENT_ID \
  -o csv > submissions.csv

echo "Edit submissions.csv and add grades, then press Enter"
read

# Import grades
canvas submissions grade-batch \
  --course-id $COURSE_ID \
  --assignment-id $ASSIGNMENT_ID \
  --file grades.csv

echo "Grades imported successfully!"

docs.title: Course Sync Tutorial
docs.text: Learn how to synchronize courses between Canvas instances.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Canvas CLI's sync feature allows you to:

  • Copy course content between instances (production ↔ sandbox)
  • Migrate courses between semesters
  • Maintain course templates

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Canvas CLI installed
  • Access to both source and destination Canvas instances
  • Appropriate permissions on both instances

docs.title: Step 1: Configure Multiple Instances
docs.text:
First, set up both Canvas instances:

# Add production instance
canvas config add --name production --url https://canvas.example.com --token YOUR_PROD_TOKEN

# Add sandbox instance
canvas config add --name sandbox --url https://canvas-sandbox.example.com --token YOUR_SANDBOX_TOKEN

Verify your instances:

canvas config list

Output: 

NAME         URL                                  DEFAULT
production   https://canvas.example.com           *
sandbox      https://canvas-sandbox.example.com

docs.title: Step 2: Identify Source Course
docs.text:
Find the course you want to sync:

canvas courses list --instance production

Note the course ID you want to sync.

docs.title: Step 3: Create Destination Course
docs.text:
If needed, create a new course on the destination:

canvas courses create \
  --instance sandbox \
  --name "CS101 - Test Copy" \
  --code "CS101-TEST"

Or identify an existing course:

canvas courses list --instance sandbox

docs.title: Step 4: Sync Course Content
docs.text:
Sync the course from production to sandbox:

canvas sync course 123 \
  --from production \
  --to sandbox \
  --destination-course 456

docs.title: Sync Options
docs.text:
Option Description --modules Sync modules and items --assignments Sync assignments --pages Sync pages --files Sync files --all Sync all content types

Example with specific content:

canvas sync course 123 \
  --from production \
  --to sandbox \
  --destination-course 456 \
  --modules \
  --assignments

docs.title: Step 5: Verify Sync
docs.text:
Check the destination course:

canvas modules list --course-id 456 --instance sandbox
canvas assignments list --course-id 456 --instance sandbox

docs.title: Development Testing
docs.text:
Sync a production course to sandbox for testing changes:

canvas sync course 123 --from production --to sandbox --all

docs.title: Semester Rollover
docs.text:
Copy a course template to create a new semester's course:

canvas sync course 100 \
  --from production \
  --to production \
  --destination-course 200 \
  --modules \
  --pages

docs.title: Multi-Institution Deployment
docs.text:
Sync course content between institutions:

# Configure second institution
canvas config add --name partner --url https://partner.instructure.com --token TOKEN

# Sync course
canvas sync course 123 --from production --to partner --all

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Enrollment Data

Sync does not copy enrollment or grade data. Only course structure and content are synced.

Incremental Sync

For large courses, sync specific content types incrementally rather than using --all.

Verify Before Production

Always sync to a sandbox first to verify the results before syncing to production.

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text: Ensure you have the required permissions: - Source: Read access to course content - Destination: Write access to create/update content

docs.title: Content Not Syncing
docs.text: Some content types have dependencies: - Module items require modules to exist first - Assignment groups should sync before assignments

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text: For large syncs, Canvas CLI automatically handles rate limiting. If you see rate limit errors, the CLI will retry automatically.

docs.title: Scripting & Automation Tutorial
docs.text: Learn how to automate Canvas tasks with shell scripts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Canvas CLI's JSON output makes it perfect for automation:

  • Integrate with shell scripts and cron jobs
  • Process data with jq
  • Build custom workflows

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Canvas CLI installed and authenticated
  • Basic shell scripting knowledge
  • jq installed (for JSON processing)

docs.title: Using JSON Output
docs.text:
Always use -o json for scripting:

# Get all course IDs
canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[].id'

# Get courses as array
courses=$(canvas courses list -o json | jq -r '.[].id')
for course in $courses; do
  echo "Processing course: $course"
done

docs.title: Filtering with jq
docs.text:
# Find active courses
canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[] | select(.workflow_state == "available")'

# Get course names containing "CS"
canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[] | select(.name | contains("CS")) | .name'

# Count enrollments
canvas users list --course-id 123 -o json | jq length

docs.title: Export All Grades
docs.text:
Export grades for all assignments in a course:

#!/bin/bash
COURSE_ID=$1

if [ -z "$COURSE_ID" ]; then
  echo "Usage: $0 <course_id>"
  exit 1
fi

# Get all assignments
assignments=$(canvas assignments list --course-id $COURSE_ID -o json | jq -r '.[].id')

# Create output directory
mkdir -p grades/$COURSE_ID

# Export each assignment's submissions
for assignment in $assignments; do
  echo "Exporting assignment $assignment..."
  canvas submissions list \
    --course-id $COURSE_ID \
    --assignment-id $assignment \
    -o csv > "grades/$COURSE_ID/assignment_$assignment.csv"
done

echo "Done! Grades exported to grades/$COURSE_ID/"

docs.title: Bulk User Enrollment
docs.text:
Enroll users from a CSV file:

#!/bin/bash
COURSE_ID=$1
CSV_FILE=$2

if [ -z "$COURSE_ID" ] || [ -z "$CSV_FILE" ]; then
  echo "Usage: $0 <course_id> <csv_file>"
  exit 1
fi

# Skip header and process each line
tail -n +2 "$CSV_FILE" | while IFS=, read -r email role; do
  echo "Enrolling $email as $role..."
  canvas enrollments create \
    --course-id $COURSE_ID \
    --user-email "$email" \
    --role "$role"
done

docs.title: Course Health Check
docs.text:
Check course configuration and report issues:

#!/bin/bash
COURSE_ID=$1

echo "=== Course Health Check ==="
echo ""

# Get course info
course=$(canvas courses get $COURSE_ID -o json)
echo "Course: $(echo $course | jq -r '.name')"
echo "State: $(echo $course | jq -r '.workflow_state')"
echo ""

# Check modules
module_count=$(canvas modules list --course-id $COURSE_ID -o json | jq length)
echo "Modules: $module_count"

# Check assignments
assignment_count=$(canvas assignments list --course-id $COURSE_ID -o json | jq length)
echo "Assignments: $assignment_count"

# Check unpublished items
unpublished=$(canvas modules list --course-id $COURSE_ID -o json | jq '[.[] | select(.published == false)] | length')
echo "Unpublished modules: $unpublished"

# Check for missing due dates
no_due_date=$(canvas assignments list --course-id $COURSE_ID -o json | jq '[.[] | select(.due_at == null)] | length')
echo "Assignments without due date: $no_due_date"

docs.title: Automated Backup
docs.text:
Back up course content daily:

#!/bin/bash
# Add to crontab: 0 2 * * * /path/to/backup.sh

BACKUP_DIR="/backups/canvas"
DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)

# Get all courses
courses=$(canvas courses list -o json | jq -r '.[].id')

for course_id in $courses; do
  course_name=$(canvas courses get $course_id -o json | jq -r '.name' | tr ' ' '_')
  output_dir="$BACKUP_DIR/$DATE/$course_name"
  mkdir -p "$output_dir"

  # Export course data
  canvas courses get $course_id -o json > "$output_dir/course.json"
  canvas modules list --course-id $course_id -o json > "$output_dir/modules.json"
  canvas assignments list --course-id $course_id -o json > "$output_dir/assignments.json"
  canvas pages list --course-id $course_id -o json > "$output_dir/pages.json"

  echo "Backed up: $course_name"
done

# Cleanup old backups (keep 30 days)
find $BACKUP_DIR -type d -mtime +30 -exec rm -rf {} \;

docs.title: Parallel Processing
docs.text:
Process multiple courses in parallel:

#!/bin/bash
# Process courses in parallel (max 4 at a time)
canvas courses list -o json | jq -r '.[].id' | \
  xargs -P 4 -I {} bash -c 'process_course {}'

process_course() {
  course_id=$1
  canvas assignments list --course-id $course_id -o json > "course_$course_id.json"
}
export -f process_course

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Robust error handling in scripts:

#!/bin/bash
set -e  # Exit on error

handle_error() {
  echo "Error on line $1"
  exit 1
}
trap 'handle_error $LINENO' ERR

# Check if canvas CLI is available
if ! command -v canvas &> /dev/null; then
  echo "Canvas CLI not found"
  exit 1
fi

# Verify authentication
if ! canvas auth status &> /dev/null; then
  echo "Not authenticated. Run: canvas auth login"
  exit 1
fi

# Your script logic here
canvas courses list -o json

docs.title: Environment-Based Configuration
docs.text:
Use different instances based on environment:

#!/bin/bash
# Set instance based on environment
case "$CANVAS_ENV" in
  production)
    INSTANCE="production"
    ;;
  staging)
    INSTANCE="sandbox"
    ;;
  *)
    INSTANCE="sandbox"  # Default to sandbox
    ;;
esac

canvas courses list --instance $INSTANCE -o json

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Test in Sandbox

Always test scripts against a sandbox instance before running on production.

Rate Limiting

Canvas CLI handles rate limiting automatically, but for large batch operations, consider adding delays.

Logging

Add timestamps and logging for long-running scripts: 

log() {
  echo "[$(date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')] $1"
}
log "Starting process..."

Credentials

Never hardcode tokens in scripts. Use environment variables or the config file.

docs.title: User Guide
docs.text: Learn how to configure and use Canvas CLI effectively.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
• Configuration

    Configure Canvas CLI for your environment, including multiple instances

    Configuration

  • Output Formats

    Learn about the different output formats available

    Output Formats

  • Shell Completion

    Set up tab completion for your shell

    Shell Completion

docs.title: Course Context
docs.text:
Most commands require a course context. You can specify this with the --course-id flag:

canvas assignments list --course-id 123

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text:
Canvas CLI supports multiple output formats:

  • table (default) - Human-readable table format
  • json - JSON for scripting and automation
  • yaml - YAML format
  • csv - CSV for spreadsheet import

docs.title: Caching
docs.text:
Canvas CLI caches API responses for better performance. You can:

  • Disable caching with --no-cache
  • Clear the cache with canvas cache clear
  • View cache statistics with canvas cache stats

docs.title: Masquerading
docs.text:
Administrators can act as other users with the --as-user flag:

canvas courses list --as-user 456

This requires masquerading permissions in Canvas.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Canvas CLI can be configured to work with multiple Canvas instances and customized for your workflow.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Canvas CLI stores configuration in ~/.canvas-cli/config.yaml.

default_instance: production
instances:
  production:
    url: https://canvas.example.com
    token: your-api-token
  sandbox:
    url: https://canvas-sandbox.example.com
    token: sandbox-token

docs.title: Add an Instance
docs.text:
# Add with API token
canvas config add --name production --url https://canvas.example.com --token YOUR_TOKEN

# Add without token (will prompt for OAuth)
canvas config add --name production --url https://canvas.example.com

docs.title: List Instances
docs.text: canvas config list

docs.title: Switch Default Instance
docs.text: canvas config use sandbox

docs.title: Remove an Instance
docs.text: canvas config remove sandbox

docs.title: Show Current Configuration
docs.text: canvas config show

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Canvas CLI supports environment variables for configuration:

Variable Description CANVAS_INSTANCE Canvas instance URL CANVAS_TOKEN API token CANVAS_OUTPUT Default output format CANVAS_NO_CACHE Disable caching (true/false)

Example:

export CANVAS_INSTANCE=https://canvas.example.com
export CANVAS_TOKEN=your-api-token
canvas courses list

docs.title: Command-Line Overrides
docs.text:
You can override configuration with command-line flags:

# Override instance
canvas courses list --instance https://other-canvas.example.com

# Override output format
canvas courses list --output json

# Disable caching
canvas courses list --no-cache

docs.title: Multiple Instances
docs.text:
Canvas CLI supports working with multiple Canvas instances. This is useful for:

  • Development vs. production environments
  • Multiple institutions
  • Testing and staging

docs.title: Switching Instances
docs.text:
# Use a specific instance for one command
canvas courses list --instance sandbox

# Switch default instance
canvas config use sandbox

docs.title: Syncing Between Instances
docs.text:
# Sync a course from production to sandbox
canvas sync course 123 --from production --to sandbox

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: Canvas CLI supports multiple output formats to suit different use cases.

docs.title: Table (Default)
docs.text:
Human-readable table format, ideal for terminal viewing.

canvas courses list

ID     NAME                    CODE       TERM
123    Introduction to CS      CS101      Fall 2024
456    Data Structures         CS201      Fall 2024
789    Algorithms              CS301      Fall 2024

docs.title: JSON
docs.text:
Structured JSON output, ideal for scripting and automation.

canvas courses list --output json

[
  {
    "id": 123,
    "name": "Introduction to CS",
    "course_code": "CS101",
    "enrollment_term_id": 1
  }
]

docs.title: YAML
docs.text:
YAML format for configuration files and human-readable structured data.

canvas courses list --output yaml

- id: 123
  name: Introduction to CS
  course_code: CS101
  enrollment_term_id: 1

docs.title: CSV
docs.text:
Comma-separated values for spreadsheet import.

canvas courses list --output csv

id,name,course_code,enrollment_term_id
123,Introduction to CS,CS101,1
456,Data Structures,CS201,1

docs.title: Bash with jq
docs.text:
# Get course IDs
canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[].id'

# Filter by name
canvas courses list -o json | jq '.[] | select(.name | contains("CS"))'

docs.title: Piping to Files
docs.text:
# Export to CSV file
canvas users list --course-id 123 -o csv > users.csv

# Export to JSON file
canvas assignments list --course-id 123 -o json > assignments.json

docs.title: Processing with Other Tools
docs.text:
# Count users
canvas users list --course-id 123 -o json | jq length

# Get specific fields
canvas users list --course-id 123 -o json | jq '.[].email'

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Use JSON for Scripts

Always use -o json when parsing output in scripts. Table format may change between versions.

CSV for Spreadsheets

Use -o csv when you need to import data into Excel, Google Sheets, or other spreadsheet applications.

Combine with grep

For quick filtering, combine table output with grep: 

canvas courses list | grep "Fall 2024"

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text: Canvas CLI supports tab completion for Bash, Zsh, Fish, and PowerShell.

docs.title: Bash
docs.text:
# Add to ~/.bashrc
source <(canvas completion bash)

# Or save to a file
canvas completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/canvas

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:
# Add to ~/.zshrc
source <(canvas completion zsh)

# Or add to fpath
canvas completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_canvas"

Oh My Zsh

If you use Oh My Zsh, save the completion script to: 

canvas completion zsh > ~/.oh-my-zsh/completions/_canvas

docs.title: Fish
docs.text: canvas completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/canvas.fish

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text:
# Add to your PowerShell profile
canvas completion powershell | Out-String | Invoke-Expression

# Or save to a file
canvas completion powershell > canvas.ps1

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Once installed, press Tab to:

  • Complete command names
  • Complete flag names
  • Complete flag values (where supported)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Complete commands
canvas cour<Tab>
# → canvas courses

# Complete subcommands
canvas courses <Tab>
# → list  get  create  update  delete

# Complete flags
canvas courses list --<Tab>
# → --output  --no-cache  --instance  --help

docs.title: Completions Not Working
docs.text:
1. Ensure the completion script is sourced in your shell config
  2. Restart your shell or source the config file
  3. Check that Canvas CLI is in your PATH

docs.title: Zsh: Command Not Found
docs.text:
If you see "command not found: compdef", add this before sourcing:

autoload -Uz compinit && compinit
